trial_identification.studytitle: The efficacy of two alternative suture anchors, Panalok and bioraptor 2.3 for primary stabilisation of the shoulder for instability and identification of risk factors for recurrence of the shoulder instability post operation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The efficacy of 2 alternative suture materials Ethibond and Panacryl used with Panalok 'suture anchors' for the primary open surgical stabilisation of the shoulder for instability - a double blind randomised trial

conditions.healthcondition: Shoulder stabilisation: shoulder instability episodes not controlled with conservative measures

interventions.interventions: Use of Panalok suture anchors with either a bioabsorbable suture (panacryl) or non- absorbable suture (ethibond) used during open surgical stabilisation of the shoulder for instability.
interventions.comparator: Use of Panalok suture anchors with either a bioabsorbable suture (panacryl) or non- absorbable suture (ethibond) used during open surgical stabilisation of the shoulder for instability

primaryOutcome.outcome: Our hypothesis is that there is no difference in outcome between panacryl and ethibond suture material when used for this procedure in which case the panacryl may be theoretically better as it dissolves away completely.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: This is assessed at 2 weeks, 12 weeks, 6 , 12 and 24 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Identification of risk factors for recurrent instability post operatively.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assesed at 12 and 24 months post operation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Informed consent. Requiring anterior shoulder stabilisation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Previous stabilisation surgery to this shoulder.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: A/Professor Simon Bell Melbourne Shoulder and Elbow Centre 31 Normanby St., Brighton 3186

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Melbourne Shoulder and Elbow Centre, 31 Normanby St., Brighton 3186 Vic, Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: During stabilisation of the shoulder which has been unstable (dislocated) the surgeon attaches back the damaged ligament to the bone with a 'Panalok" suture anchor. This is tied into place with a separate suture made of either panacryl which dissolves or ethibond which does not. The hypothesis is that there is no differenvce between the sutures but the bioabsorbable (dissolving) suture theoretically should be preferred because is disolves away completed and reduces the risk of foreign body reactions. The sutures are dyed the same colour so the surgeon, the patient , the ward staff and outcome assessors are blinded

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Mercy aged and Health Care and Monash University HREC
